bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Vernon McKenzie, July 18, 1955

div1.p: Tate testifies to the work done by Lambert as a nurse during the yellow fever experiments, and feels that Lambert should be recognized for his service. He also encloses a letter from Barratt O'Hara.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Vernon McKenzie, July 18, 1955
div1.opener:
Retained copy. Air-mailed to - Maj. McKenzie
Hon O'Hara
Gus. Lambert
July 19 '55
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, 3, California
July 18, 1955
Major Vernon McKenzie
Office of The Surgeon General
U. S. Army
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
In compliance with the request of the Honorable Barrett
O'Hara, contained in the enclosed letter, I take oath to
the following statement regarding Gustaf E. Lambert:

I was the medical clerk at Columbia Barracks Army Hospi-
tal, Quemados, Cuba, from September 9, 1900 to August
11, 1901, covering the entire period of the yellow fever
experiments conducted by the Major Walter Reed Board.

Private Gustaf E. Lambert was a member of that Hospital
Detachment, and I knew him well.

I performed all the Army medical paper work for this
hospital. As I made out all the Muster Rolls and other
reports, and handled all Special Orders relating thereto,
I was well acquainted with all changes and transfers of
the men and their duties at all times.

In this respect I know that Gustav E. Lambert was on duty
in the Yellow Fever Section before and all through the
entire period of these yellow fever experiments as nurse
for the yellow fever patients, and that he had entire charge
of these buildings, under direction of Doctor Roger Ames,
(Contract Doctor, later Major of Volunteers.)

In this capacity Lambert nursed many yellow fever cases,
including ALL of the volunteers who had contracted the
disease. Furthermore, he was the ONLY nurse there except
for two female practical nurses, (immunes) who assisted on
just one of latter cases.

Lambert faced greater risk of contraction yellow fever, as he
was not immune.

It has always been acknowledged that the fate of this great
experiment depended on the experience and work of Doctor
✓ Ames and Nurse Lambert, for if but one of the earlier cases
had died, popular clamor in Cuba and the U. S. combined
with the disinclination of Major Reed to risk human lives,
would have ruined all chance of proving the Finlay theory.

I further know that Lambert did not have to work so long
(2)
on such a dangerous and distasteful job. He volunteered to
keep at it through his loyalty to Doctor Ames and Medical
Science.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, Paul L Tate Paul L. Tate
Kindly read remarks on following pages.
Notarized
P.S.- I notice that Mr. O'Hara in quoting the unfavorable
report of the Secretary of the Army did not complete the
entire sentence.
It occurs to me that this ommission may have had reference
to the Army policy that there was to be no more reopening
of this Act of 1929 which honored the members of the Yellow
Fever Commission and those who offered their bodies for
experiment. If it did I thoroly agree with it.--Too many
have attempted to take undeserved honors in this event.
Yet, there but TWO men, not honored, who were important to
the success of the experiment: They were Doctor Ames and
Nurse Lambert.--It is quite probable that without these two
the experiment would have failed.
If this is the cause, why cannot it be left to a Congress-
ional Committee? Congress made the recognition. If a member
of Congress desires to have that body recognize another in
in this experiment which a former congress overlooked, why
should the Army attempt to prevent recognition of one of its
own former service man?
I feel sure that Lambert, no matter how his Congressman's
bill reads, expects no money, but perhaps a medal showing
the Congressional recognition which he deserves.
PLT
ADDENDUM:
In connection with the foregoing it appears strange that the
Army can find no record of Lambert's work with the Yellow Fever
Commission. If the old Muster Rolls have been preserved, the
record is there. I have read many articles about this experi-
ment in which his name was mentioned.
For instance, your The Surgeon General of the Army, Major Gen-
eral George E. Armstrong, in 1950, having learned from the
late Brigadier General Albert Truby that I desired a copy of
the latter's book, “Memoir of Walter Reed”(then out of print)
very kindly personally sent me a copy of that book with the
compliments of the Army Medical Department, with one of the
very nice letters that he knows so well how to write.
In that story of the Yellow Fever Experiment, General Truby,
who was Commanding Officer of Columbia Hospital for quite a
while, refers to Lambert many times. Lambert's picture is there
with the rest of the Detachment on page 154. He states he re-
ceived much of his discription of the strictly quarantined
yellow fever section from Lambert.
On page 81 he says: “A private of our Hospital Corps Detachment,
G. E. Lambert, was dubbed by the men as ‘Ames’ Man Friday.’ He
was most loyal and faithful. Ames had this to say of him in a
letter dated November 12, 1901:
“During the epidemic at Quemados, near Columbia Barracks, Cuba,
he was always my important right hand man. Nearly all cases of
yellow fever (over 67), either natural or experimental, at-
tended by me in part or whole, were nursed by this competent
soldier. The general supervision of the yellow fever wards and
the running of the large disinfecting plant was entrusted to
his care.”
I have a copy of a letter from Major Kean, Surgeon General of
Western Cuba at that time, to Lambert, acknowledging Lambert's
fine treatment of him when he had yellow fever.
I have corresponded for a long time with Doctor Philip S. Hench,
of Mayo Clinic, who has for many years been writing the only
complete history of the yellow fever experiment, and who has met
most of the volunteers, and he tells me that Lambert will have
a prominent place in his book. He procured lots of his material
from Army records. Why can't the Army find Lambert?
So, it appears very strange that so many people, including
officers of the Army, such as General Truby, Major Kean and
others who were present at the experiment and knew of Lambert
and his highly valuable services to the experiment, yet the
present Army can find no record of him:
If Lambert were permitted to appear before a Committee he has
(page 2, Addendum)
plenty of convincing material relating to his work on the
Yellow Fever Experiment, including letters from many of the
volunteers, thanking him for his fine services and the probable
saving of their life.
I hope that in simple justice to a soldier who served the
Medical Departmet of the Army and humanity so well and is now
old and disabled, that he will be given at least the chance to
present his case.--It is all he asks. Anything less would not
carry out the “Old Army” watchword of HONOR.
So, I ask you to use whatever influence you have to help do
simple justice to this deserving man.
Sincerely yours,
Paul L. Tate
Paul L. Tate
